byline.contributor: David E. Sanger reported from Vienna, and William J. Broad from New York.
byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER and WILLIAM J. BROAD

abstract: International inspectors from International Atomic Energy Agency are preparing to use new, and far more sophisticated, surveillance equipment to monitor Iran's nuclear infrastructure; Iran has often limited inspectors to older technologies, which has slowed inspection process and weakened its accuracy and efficiency.
lead_paragraph: Laser sensors, smart cameras and encrypted networks are at the ready to monitor a program that has been a challenge for older technologies.

headline.main: Awaiting Iran Deal, Nuclear Sleuths Gather Sophisticated Tools
headline.print_headline: Awaiting Iran Deal, Inspectors Prepare New Tools

snippet: Laser sensors, smart cameras and encrypted networks are at the ready to monitor a program that has been a challenge for older technologies.
